entry.title: bacterial motility (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that swimming and swarming are forms of bacterial motility, which some bacteria achieve by rotating a small whip-like flagellum (depicted)?

entry.title: Harriet Amelia Folsom (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Harriet Amelia Folsom went by her middle name, so as not to be confused with her husband Brigham Young's other wives?

entry.title: a series of campaigns against Germanic tribes (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the Romans won a series of campaigns against Germanic tribes after the disaster at Teutoburg but decided to leave Germany as the effort was out of proportion to the territory's value?

entry.title: Dianxi Xiaoge (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Dianxi Xiaoge, who grew up in a remote Yunnan mountain village without running water, is an Internet celebrity with roughly 16 million subscribers on all her platforms?

entry.title: two boats and a helicopter (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the "two boats and a helicopter" parable has been used to combat COVID-19 vaccine hesitancy?

entry.title: Andrea-Mae Zepeda (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that in September 2021, cricketer Andrea-Mae Zepeda became the first player to score a century for Austria in a Women's Twenty20 International match?

entry.title: Prise d'Orange (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that part of Prise d'Orange was recently discovered in the binding of another book?

entry.title: George Asprey (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that George Asprey was not born with a silver spoon in his mouth – according to the Daily Mirror, it was a silver shovel?
